Award.AwardTitle: CNH: Cooking Up Clean Air: Scaled-Up Air Quality and Health Impacts of Clean Cookstoves in Ghana
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nearly half the world?s population, mostly in the developing world, cooks over open flames on a daily basis. This releases greenhouse gas and exposes people to toxic emissions that contribute to respiratory disease. In Ghana and other countries in the "meningitis belt," emissions from cooking have been linked to meningitis. We hypothesize that widespread use of efficient, or "clean", cookstoves - which produce less smoke than open fires even while burning the same available materials - will reduce people's exposure to toxic emissions, improve health outcomes, and improve regional air quality. To test this hypothesis, we will introduce cookstoves into households in northern Ghana. In addition to determining whether they do, in fact, improve air quality and health outcomes, we will explore the social and economic factors that encourage or discourage cook stove use, and consider the impacts of climate change. Our methods combine 1) a randomized experiment intended to increase use of efficient cookstoves; 2) social surveys to measure effects on cooking behavior and self-reported health outcomes; 3) collection of physical data to measure the impacts on emissions and air quality; 4) integrated modeling of the relationships among cooking practices, air quality, climate variability, respiratory illness and bacterial meningitis; and 5) simulations of emissions and climate change scenarios and their potential impacts on regional air quality and health outcomes over time.

Our results will enhance understanding of the social and physical systems that shape air quality in the African Sahel and particularly in northern Ghana, contribute valuable observations in a part of the world where observations are sparse, and empower communities in Africa. The work will provide quantitative knowledge that can be used to develop novel strategies to control the spread of meningitis in the face of future threats. Our results will also shed light on the interactions among human behavior, air quality, climate variability, exposure, and health outcomes, and how future changes in these factors may combine in Africa and other areas. Affordable and effective instrumentation developed and applied as part of this project will be tested and available for use in areas around the globe. Further, we will develop novel university curricula and train African and American university students in data collection. Finally, our participatory epidemiology approach, in which community members help measure air quality and report disease, will empower local communities that do not have access to vaccines. Ultimately, we will work with communities to generate scenarios in which realistic changes in cooking practices interact with climatic processes to produce improvements in air quality that reduce the burden of respiratory illness and bacterial meningitis in the African Sahel.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Research of Emissions, Air quality, Climate, and Cooking Technologies In Northern Ghana (REACCTING) project is a multi-disciplinary effort to evaluate the impact of improved cooking technologies on behavior, cooking emissions, air quality and health outcomes. Two improved biomass cookstoves were chosen for this study based on cost, technology, and country of origin: a locally-made rocket stove and the Philips forced-draft stove. Two hundred randomly selected rural households in the Kassena-Nankana districts of Northern Ghana were divided into four groups of 50. Three of the four groups were given a combination of the two improved stoves in December 2013; the last was a control group and received their choice of two stoves at the end of the field sampling in 2016. The impacts of the stoves on behavior, emissions, air quality, exposures and health were determined with a variety of measurement techniques. Surveys and stove use monitors were used to assess use of improved and traditional stoves over a two-year period. Personal exposure and microenvironment measurements were collected and analyzed to assess the impact of cooking activities. In-field emission measurements of reactive trace gases and particles were measured for a variety of stove/fuel combinations. Health effects were measured through dried blood spot samples analyzed for biomarkers of inflammation associated with smoke exposure. Ambient measurements of key air pollutants were measured in rural and urban areas throughout the study region. The integration of the various field data across multiple temporal and spatial scales with statistical models (eg. multiresolution hazard models and mixed-effects models). While prior stove intervention studies have included a subset of these measurements, a key contribution of the REACCTING study is its comprehensive, interdisciplinary set of measurements on a variety of indicators linking the introduction of new stoves with environmental, social, and health outcomes.

 

Overall, the outcomes of this this project highlighted the impacts of traditional and clean stove use in a rural region of the African Sahel. Study participants valued smoke reduction and the need for less fuel when cooking. However, traditional stove use continued despite the availability and access to new technologies, and stove stacking (use of multiple types of stoves) was common. Use of the Ghanaian-made rocket stove was higher than use of the Philips forced-draft stove, but use of both types of improved stoves declined over time. Participants found the new stoves less suitable than traditional stoves for cooking certain dishes, including a local staple porridge.

 

Despite the continued stove stacking and the reduction of improved stove usage over time, personal exposure to particulate carbonaceous particulate matter was lower in the intervention groups when compared to the control group. The personal exposure measurements also indicated that, while biomass burning was a substantial contributor to personal PM exposure, other sources were important. Direct, in-field emission measurements characterized the difference in the gaseous and particulate matter emissions from the traditional and improved stoves. Differences in these emissions between stoves were not always significant, and were dependent on the fuel/stove type, suggesting that the improved stoves may not lead to the expected reductions in emissions. The emissions data are used to build emissions inventories for continental Africa. As part of this project, the Diffuse and Inefficient Combustion Emissions in Africa (DICE-Africa) inventory was developed for use in chemical and climate models and provides a baseline for future studies of global and technological change.

 

To date, this project has produced more than 20 publications and conference presentations, with several additional products in development. New measurement, analytical, and computing tools have been developed as part of the various project components. Six graduate students, three undergraduate, and two post-doctoral researchers were trained as part of this project. Additionally, multiple K-12 activities were completed, including the mentorship of five high school students and a group of middle school students. Two classes (in engineering and in environmental studies) were developed drawing on methods and experiences from this project, providing educational opportunities for undergraduates and graduate students not directly involved in this project. A web site has been developed to provide a public outlet for this project. Several models and computing tools were developed for data analysis. Further, this project launched additional grant-funded work on emissions sources, measurement techniques, and the adoption of stove technologies. Collectively, this work will enable a better understanding of the potential for future technological advances and their impact on the human/earth system interactions.
